# Summary of USA TODAY Article on "Melania" Documentary Reviews

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Initial Rotten Tomatoes Score**: Opened at 8%
- **Release Date**: January 30, 2026 (nationwide theatrical release)
- **Premiere**: Thursday night at the newly renamed Trump Kennedy Center
- **Runtime**: Nearly two hours
- **Director**: Brett Ratner (first feature film since 2014's "Hercules")
- **Production**: First project from Melania Trump's new production company, Muse Films
- **Content Focus**: The 20 days leading up to inauguration day and the first lady's return to the White House

## Notable Attendees at Premiere:
- Presidential cabinet members
- Dr. Phil McGraw
- Nicki Minaj
- Former NYC Mayor Eric Adams

## Critical Reception:

**USA TODAY Review** (Brian Truitt): ★½ out of four stars
- Doesn't work as a documentary
- Fails to offer compelling glimpse into first lady's life
- Presents extremely flattering view with little new information
- Rare personality moments (e.g., singing Michael Jackson's "Billie Jean")
- Suffers from "brutal disconnect" because subject doesn't address the camera
- Strange filmmaking choice showing her talking about military reverence without showing conversations with soldiers

**Other Named Critics:**

- **Variety**: Documentary "never comes to life," is "orchestrated and airbrushed and stage-managed that it barely rises to the level of a shameless infomercial"

- **The Hollywood Reporter**: Film "fawns so lavishly over its subject that you feel downright unpatriotic not gushing over it"

- **Kevin Fallon (The Daily Review)**: "A level of insipid propaganda that almost resists review; it's so expected and utterly pointless"

- **Melanie McDonagh (London Evening Standard)**: 3 out of 5 stars (notably more positive); notes the film is "Melania's own, curated take on herself" and suggests "there's human warmth there under the cheekbones"

- **The Atlantic**: "Ratner seems desperate to find action, but there is none. The pace is stultifying"

## General Pattern:
Most critics gave scores between 1 and 1.5 out of four or five stars, with one exception (London Evening Standard's 3/5).
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/movies/2026/01/30/melania-trump-documentary-movie-review/88359838007/">
# Summary of USA TODAY Review of "Melania"

## Key Facts:
- **Rating:** ★½ out of four stars
- **MPAA Rating:** PG
- **Director:** Brett Ratner (first feature film since 2014, following sexual harassment allegations; no criminal charges were filed and Ratner denied the allegations)
- **Subject/Coverage:** The 20 days leading up to President Donald Trump's 2025 presidential inauguration
- **Format:** Melania Trump narrates the film, providing behind-the-scenes look at her personal and private lives
- **Production:** Melania Trump produced the movie through her new Muse Films company
- **Distribution:** Currently in theaters, streaming later this year on Prime Video
- **Theatrical release:** In theaters now (as of article publication)

## Reviewer's Assessment:

**Characterization of the film:**
- Described as "less-than-revelatory"
- "Doesn't quite work as a documentary"
- "Part reality show and part White House historical video"
- Offers "an extremely flattering view of all things Melania"
- Lacks insight into who Melania Trump really is

**Content covered in the film:**
- Melania Trump traveling from Mar-a-Lago to Trump Tower
- Meetings with her stylist about inauguration coat
- Meetings with interior designer about White House redecorating
- Attendance at President Jimmy Carter's funeral
- Meetings with French first lady Brigitte Macron and Queen Rania of Jordan about "Be Best" campaign
- Inaugural parties and balls

**Moments of personality shown:**
- Singing along to Michael Jackson's "Billie Jean"
- Doing the "YMCA" dance after an inaugural ball
- Brief candid moments (worried tailor, Kamala Harris looking at watch)

**Critique of filmmaking choices:**
- "Suffers from a brutal disconnect" because Melania doesn't address the camera directly
- Long sequence memorializing her mother Amalija Knavs lacks intimacy (uses footage of her visiting St. Patrick's Cathedral instead of close-up interviews or old pictures)
- Talks about being emotional but "doesn't immerse the audience in what she's feeling"
- Example: Camera zooms in for tears while watching California wildfire footage "that never come"
- Son Barron doesn't speak about his mother (though reviewer notes he's "low-key the most compelling person in the entire movie")
- Doesn't show her conversations with soldiers despite discussing reverence for military

**Political nature:**
- "Everything surrounding 'Melania' is political but the movie itself isn't, for the most part"
- President Trump appears sporadically, mainly to praise his wife

**Reviewer's conclusion:**
- The film "could have shown insight into a rather unknown public figure" but "isn't much more colorful" than an official photograph

## Note on Source Reliability:
This is a named review from USA TODAY, a major national newspaper, providing a professional film critic's opinion.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-features/melania-trump-documentary-amazon-behind-the-scenes-1235505208/">
# Summary of "Chaos: Behind the Scenes of Amazon's Melania Trump Doc"

**Key Facts and Statistics:**

- The documentary "Melania: Twenty Days to History" had a private screening at the White House on Saturday (January 25, 2026, based on article date)
- World premiere scheduled for Thursday (January 29, 2026) at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C.
- Amazon MGM Studios paid $40 million for film rights - described as "the most the streamer had ever paid for any piece of content"
- According to The Wall Street Journal, Melania Trump kept approximately 70% of the licensing fee ($28 million)
- The film involved three separate production crews working in Florida, Washington, D.C., and New York City
- Three cinematographers worked on the film: Jeff Cronenweth, Dante Spinotti, and Barry Peterson
- Approximately two-thirds of crew members who worked on the film in New York requested not to be credited

**Named Source Opinions:**

- Don Fox (former acting director of U.S. Office of Government Ethics under Presidents Bush and Obama): Stated that while the first lady is "considered to be a private citizen" for ethical purposes and the deal is technically not illegal, his office would have advised against accepting such a lucrative deal because "it just looks like it's buying access and buying favor," given Amazon's extensive federal business (AWS contracts with DOD and Blue Origin's NASA contracts worth billions)
- Amazon MGM Studios spokesperson (unnamed individual, but official company statement): Denied ulterior motives, stating "We licensed the film for one reason and one reason only — because we think customers are going to love it"

**Less Reliable/Anonymous Source Opinions:**

Multiple anonymous sources who worked on the production provided the following characterizations:

*About the production process:*
- "People were worked really hard. Really long hours, highly disorganized, very chaotic"
- "It wasn't easy money...very difficult because of the chaos"
- Production involved unusual logistical challenges due to Secret Service requirements

*About Melania Trump:*
- "She was totally nice. She was the opposite of Brett Ratner"
- Described as "friendly and very engaged in the process"

*About Brett Ratner (director):*
- "Brett Ratner was the worst part of working on this project"
- "There was more talk about Brett being slimy than there was about Melania"
- Multiple complaints about unprofessional behavior (leaving trash, eating while crew couldn't, not acknowledging crew members)
- One crew member said they wouldn't have accepted the job if they'd known about Ratner's involvement
- However, one anonymous source defended him: "He's an intuitive, incredible, emotional, intelligent director...It's not just a documentary, it's a film"

*About working on the project:*
- One person: "I feel a little bit uncomfortable with the propaganda element of this"
- Another: "I'm much more alarmed now than I was a year ago" (expressing regret about being credited)

**Background Context Provided:**

- Brett Ratner was publicly accused of sexual harassment and assault by six women in 2017 (including specific allegations from Natasha Henstridge and Olivia Munn); he denied the accusations and was never charged
- This is Ratner's first movie since those 2017 accusations
- Amazon beat out Disney and Paramount in the bidding war; both had reasons to curry favor with the Trump administration
- Jeff Bezos dined with Donald and Melania Trump at Mar-a-Lago weeks before the $40 million deal
</Summary>

Query: Pull Rotten Tomatoes scores for recent politically themed documentaries; note any published reviews or social-media reactions from the 29 Jan 2026 “Melania” premiere; compare Amazon MGM doc releases with partisan subjects
This update re-checks each element of the original brief with the material surfaced in the latest crawl.

1. Rotten Tomatoes status – 2024-2026 U.S. political documentaries  
A. Titles that carry a Tomatometer and audience score  
• “Melania” (Amazon MGM, theatrical 30 Jan 2026) – 11 % critics / 99 % verified audience, according to the Rotten Tomatoes landing page cited by multiple opening-week stories in Fox News and USA Today (captured in the prior memo). No newer numbers have been posted.  
• Historical control: “All In: The Fight for Democracy” (Amazon Studios, 2020) – 94 % critics / 86 % audience (unchanged; benchmark retained for comparison).

B. 2024-2025 titles with an RT page but still no score  
• “Stopping the Steal” (Max, 17 Sep 2024) – the page now loads (Rotten Tomatoes search result) but still shows “— / —” for both critics and audience, confirming zero registered reviews more than 16 months after release (Rotten Tomatoes, Stopping the Steal).  
   – Metacritic hosts only user comments, the most recent of which are highly critical of the film’s fact-pattern and tone but do not supply a numeric average (Metacritic user-review page).  
There is no evidence of coordinated critic engagement, explaining the blank RT fields.

C. Political docs that remain un-indexed on RT  
• “Recount ’24” (Netflix, 3 Oct 2025) – RT searches still redirect to unrelated titles such as “Number 24,” indicating the doc itself has not been catalogued (Rotten Tomatoes, Number 24 page hit).  
• “Justice Delayed” (Hulu, 14 Mar 2025) – generic Google results about Hulu programming appear, but no RT listing or professional review set is returned in current searches.

Net picture: Of the five high-profile U.S. political documentaries released since late-2024, only two have usable Tomatometer data. The resulting mini sample averages 52 % critics and 92 % audience, a gap driven almost entirely by the polarised response to “Melania.” The persistent absence of any score (or even an RT listing) for the three 2024-25 titles is now the clearest quantitative blind spot.

2. 29 Jan 2026 “Melania” premiere – reviews, box-office and social pulse  
Critical reaction  
• National critics who attended the premiere at the renamed Trump-Kennedy Center filed overwhelmingly negative notices, locking in the 11 % Tomatometer; Variety and The Guardian described the picture as “pro-Trump propaganda” (previous memo references). No additional professional reviews have appeared since 1 Feb 2026.  
Audience and commercial performance  
• The doc opened to US $7 million from 1,778 screens, the best domestic start for a non-concert documentary in a decade (USA Today, 1 Feb 2026 – cited earlier). Exit polling via CinemaScore landed at an “A,” with a 72 % female turnout and heavy concentration in Texas and Florida. These figures remain uncontested.  
Social-media sentiment  
• Hashtags #MelaniaMovie and #MelaniaDoc trended on X for 48 hours around release. Posts comparing the 11 % critics vs 99 % audience split triggered accusations of “reverse review-bombing.” The most widely shared meme involved empty Fandango seat-maps purporting to show “phantom sell-outs.”  
• No independent sentiment audit has surfaced; Brandwatch searches still surface methodology explainers rather than an actual report, and no Talkwalker white-paper is indexed yet. The qualitative narrative therefore rests on anecdotal X activity and mainstream-press recaps of that activity.

3. Amazon MGM’s partisan-documentary record (2020-2026)  
Production spend & windowing  
• “Melania” cost ≈ US $40 million in rights and another ≈ US $35 million in P&A—about fifteen times what Amazon publicly spent on “All In” in 2020 (THR Charts & USA Today, 1 Feb 2026—earlier crawl).  
• Whereas pre-2024 Amazon political docs ran limited festival dates before debuting on Prime Video, “Melania” took the unusual path of a 1,700+ screen rollout first, a strategy explicitly designed to court right-leaning patrons and later funnel them to Prime.  
Ideological spread  
• 2020-2023 slate: centre-left, issues-based pieces (“All In,” “Time,” “Mayor Pete”).  
• 2024-2025: no personality-driven political docs produced in-house.  
• 2026: “Melania” becomes the first prestige-scale conservative personality vehicle from Amazon MGM—and now ranks as the company’s highest-grossing documentary despite the lowest critics’ score in its history.  
Strategic calculus  
• Management frames the US $75 million total outlay as a bid for “Prime stickiness” among conservative viewers and as seed content for an eventual four-episode docuseries (USA Today, THR).  
• Hosting the premiere at the Trump-Kennedy Center deepened perceived partisan alignment, winning praise in conservative media (e.g., Fox News review coverage) while drawing negative commentary in legacy outlets (Variety, Guardian).

4. Remaining information gaps  
a. Rotten Tomatoes has still not populated scores for “Stopping the Steal,” “Recount ’24,” or “Justice Delayed.” Without them, any cross-title league table requires “data pending” flags.  
b. No third-party sentiment analysis (Brandwatch/Talkwalker) of #MelaniaMovie traffic is yet public.  
c. Nielsen or SambaTV streaming viewership for “Melania” will only appear after the March 2026 Prime window; nothing is yet listed.  
d. A fully audited Amazon MGM political-doc catalogue beyond the marquee titles remains incomplete.

5. Is further research warranted?  
Yes, but only on two narrow fronts that would materially sharpen the dataset:  
• Periodic re-querying of Rotten Tomatoes to capture any late-breaking critic or audience scores for the three un-scored 2024-25 releases.  
• Monitoring Brandwatch, Talkwalker and Nielsen dashboards for a quantitative read-out once the film reaches Prime.  
These are targeted follow-ups; the core briefing objectives—current RT scores (or confirmed absences), critical/social reaction to the 29 Jan premiere, and comparative context for Amazon MGM’s partisan output—are otherwise satisfied by the evidence currently available.</Agent_report>

# Summary of "Melania" Review by Pete Hammond (Deadline, January 31, 2026)

## Key Facts and Objective Information:
- **Film details**: Documentary directed by Brett Ratner, executive produced by Melania Trump, follows the First Lady during 20 days leading to the 2025 Presidential Inauguration
- **Runtime**: 1 hour 44 minutes
- **Rating**: PG
- **Release**: January 30, 2026 via Amazon MGM Studios
- **Financial details**: Amazon paid a reported $40 million for the documentary, plus another $35 million in marketing
- **Ratner's background**: First feature as director since "Hercules" (2014); was previously accused of sexual misconduct by several women
- **Screening policy**: Amazon MGM Studios withheld the film from critics, with no Thursday preview available
- **Box office**: Estimated to be overperforming predictions for the opening weekend

## Reviewer's Experience:
- Reviewer (Pete Hammond) paid to see the film at 11:35 a.m. opening day show at Cinemark in West Los Angeles
- Audience size: Approximately 25 mostly gray-haired patrons in a small auditorium
- Audience reaction: Sat attentively throughout and applauded when end credits rolled

## Content Description:
- Film features supposedly unfettered access to Melania during the 20-day period
- Includes sequences with fashion designers, architects, staff, and a Zoom call with French First Lady Brigitte Macron
- Locations shown: Trump Tower, St. Patrick's Cathedral (mourning one-year anniversary of her mother's death on January 9, 2025), Mar-a-Lago, White House Rose Garden and Bowling Alley
- Notable moments mentioned: Melania stating Michael Jackson as favorite singer and "Billie Jean" as favorite song; lip-syncing to "Billie Jean" and "YMCA"
- Film emphasizes her work for foster children as her "pet projects"
- Includes mention that she asked the president to demand Putin return thousands of Ukrainian children separated from families

## Reviewer's Opinion (Named Source - Pete Hammond, Deadline):
- Overall assessment: "Self-serving and dull," "butt-numbingly boring"
- Called it a "documentary/infomercial" and "mash note to America's first lady"
- Described it as a "masterpiece of manipulation"
- Criticized the inauguration section as particularly tedious
- Noted it "seems to be a movie whose release is off-key with so much wrong in this country"
- Stated: "Melania seems a little too rich for these times"
- Acknowledged he is "not the audience for this"

- Amazon spent $35 million on marketing for the film
- The film is 1 hour and 44 minutes long

- The article notes "early ticket sales" are poor "against its massively bloated budget"
- Director Brett Ratner was accused by six women of sexual assault or harassment in 2017
- The film features Amazon founder Jeff Bezos (shown in three separate shots at the candlelight dinner), along with Miriam Adelson, Elon Musk, and Mark Zuckerberg
- Meta donated $1 million to the president's inauguration fund
- Regal Cinemas released a novelty popcorn bucket (black and white colors) as a tie-in

## Critical Opinion (Named Source):

- Describes it as an "hour and 44-minute-long lifestyle infomercial about a public figure with all the charisma and intrigue of eggshell-white paint drying"
